ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Age in years
Visit name
Version/code of assessment
Charlson Comorbidity: have asthma
Charlson Comorbidity: take medicines for asthma
Charlson Comorbidity: when usually take medicine for asthma
Charlson Comorbidity: have Alzheimer's Disease/other dementia
Charlson Comorbidity: ever had heart attack
Charlson Comorbidity: ever treated for heart failure
Charlson Comorbidity: had operation to unclog or bypass arteries in legs
Charlson Comorbidity: had stroke, cerebrovascular accident, blood clot or bleeding in brain, or transient ischemic attack (TIA)
Charlson Comorbidity: have cancer, other than skin cancer, leukemia or lymphoma
Charlson Comorbidity: have diabetes (high blood sugar)
Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes not treated/watchful waiting
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; Blank= Missing Form/Incomplete Workbook

ElementDescription: Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes treated by modifying diet
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; Blank= Missing Form/Incomplete Workbook

ElementDescription: Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes treated with medications taken by mouth
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; Blank= Missing Form/Incomplete Workbook

ElementDescription: Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes treated with insulin injections
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; Blank = Missing Form/Incomplete Workbook

ElementDescription: Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes has not caused problems
Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes caused problems with eyes, treated by ophthalmologist
Charlson Comorbidity: diabetes caused problems with kidneys
Charlson Comorbidity: ever had problem with kidneys, poor kidney function (blood tests showed high creatinine)
Charlson Comorbidity: ever had problem with kidneys, received kidney transplant
Charlson Comorbidity: have cirrhosis or serious liver damage
Charlson Comorbidity: have emphysema, chronic bronchitis, or chronic obstructive lung disease (also called COPD)
Charlson Comorbidity: take medicines for lung disease
Charlson Comorbidity: when usually take medicine for lung disease
Charlson Comorbidity: have rheumatoid arthritis
Charlson Comorbidity: take medicines for rheumatoid arthritis regularly
Charlson Comorbidity: have polymyalgia rheumatica
Charlson Comorbidity: have stomach ulcers or peptic ulcer disease
Charlson Comorbidity: stomach ulcers or peptic ulcer disease diagnosed by endoscopy, upper GI or barium swallow study
Comorbidity Score
